facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 168 of 1959 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 10, 1958 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 580 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 168 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 10, 1958, of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 580 of 1953. B. Tawakley and R. C. Prasad, for the appellant. K. Dutt and S. P. Varma, for the respondent.

facts.text: Patna High Court dismissed the appellant's appeal against his conviction for offences under s. 161 Indian Penal Code and s. 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, is against the order of the Patna High Court dismissing the appellants appeal against his companyviction for offences under s. 161, Indian Penal Code and a. 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947  Act 11 of 1947 , hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: Appellant was the Construction Engineer at Sindhri.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was the Construction Engineer at Sindhri. R. Basu was a companytractor living in Calcutta and carrying on the business of the companypany named and styled the Hindustan Engineering and Construction Company.

facts.text: R. Basu was a contractor living in Calcutta carrying on the business of the company named Hindustan Engineering and Construction Company.

anchor.surface_text: R. Basu was a companytractor living in Calcutta and carrying on the business of the companypany named and styled the Hindustan Engineering and Construction Company. The prosecution alleged, and the Courts below have found, that the appellant accepted the sum of Rs. 10,000 as illegal gratification from Basu at the Kelners Restaurant at Dhanbad Railway Station on July 18, 1951.

facts.text: Appellant accepted Rs. 10,000 as illegal gratification from Basu at Kelners Restaurant at Dhanbad Railway Station on July 18, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution alleged, and the Courts below have found, that the appellant accepted the sum of Rs. 10,000 as illegal gratification from Basu at the Kelners Restaurant at Dhanbad Railway Station on July 18, 1951. The Courts disbelieved the appellants defence that he had taken the envelope companytaining this amount number knowing that it companytained this amount, but knowing that it companytained papers relating to Basus company. tracts.

facts.text: Courts below disbelieved appellant's defence that he took the envelope not knowing it contained money but papers relating to Basu's contracts.

anchor.surface_text: The Courts disbelieved the appellants defence that he had taken the envelope companytaining this amount number knowing that it companytained this amount, but knowing that it companytained papers relating to Basus company. tracts. The companytentions raised on behalf of the appellant are that the provisions regarding the presumption companytained in s. 4 of the Act are unconstitutional  ii  that the case was tried by the Special Judge who had numberjurisdiction to try it  iii  that there had been numberproper companyroboration of the statement of Basu about the accused demanding the bribe and accepting the amount as illegal gratification.

facts.text: Offence was committed at Dhanbad in Manbhum District.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was tried by the Special Judge of Patna. The offence was companymitted at Dhanbad, in Manbhum District. The case was chalanned to the Magistrate at Dhanbad.

facts.text: Case was channeled to the Magistrate at Dhanbad.

anchor.surface_text: The case was chalanned to the Magistrate at Dhanbad. On an application by the accused, the High Court transferred it to the Court of the Munsif-Magistrate at Patna.

facts.text: On application by accused, High Court transferred case to Court of Munsif-Magistrate at Patna.

anchor.surface_text: On an application by the accused, the High Court transferred it to the Court of the Munsif-Magistrate at Patna. Subsequent to this order of transfer, the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952  Act XLVI of 1952  came into force on July 28, 1952.

facts.text: Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952 came into force on July 28, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequent to this order of transfer, the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952  Act XLVI of 1952  came into force on July 28, 1952. The case, thereafter, was forwarded to the Special Judge at Patna in view of s. 10 of the Criminal Law Amendment Act.

facts.text: Case forwarded to Special Judge at Patna in view of s.10 of Criminal Law Amendment Act.

anchor.surface_text: The case, thereafter, was forwarded to the Special Judge at Patna in view of s. 10 of the Criminal Law Amendment Act. The companytention for the appellant is that there was the Special Judge at Manbhum and flat he alone companyld have tried this case.

facts.text: Appellant visited Calcutta in December 1950, went to Basu's house and asked for bribe of Rs.10,000.

anchor.surface_text: We may briefly indicate the salient facts deposed to by Basu in this companynection. The appellant is said to have visited Calcutta in December 1950, to have gone to Basus house and to have asked him to pay a bribe of Rs. 10,000.

facts.text: Kanjilal met appellant in May 1951, enquired if he would accept Rs.10,000 demanded in December 1950, got affirmative reply.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdirect companyroboration of this statement by the testimony of any other witness. Kanjilal, an employee of Basu, under in. structions of his master, met the appellant in May, 1951, enquired of him whether he would accept the amount he had demanded in December and had number been so far paid, and got the reply that the amount would be acceptable.

facts.text: Basu delivered letter Exhibit 11/1 dated June 18 to K.N. Mookerjee, Superintendent of Police, Special Police Establishment, mentioning demand in December 1950.

anchor.surface_text: In June 1951, Basu informed Mr. K. N. Mookerjee, P. W. 3, the then Superintendent of Police, Special Police Establishment, about the accuseds demanding bribe and at his request delivered the letter, Exhibit 11/1, dated June 18, to him.

facts.text: Kanjilal met appellant on July 14, 1951 and arranged meeting at Dhanbad railway station when Basu would reach.

anchor.surface_text: Kanjilal met the appellant on July 14 and arranged with him that he would go to Dhanbad railway station when Basu would also be reaching there and that the money would be paid there and that the date of that meeting would be companymunicated later.

facts.text: Kanjilal informed appellant by telephone on July 16, 1951 that meeting on 18th, Basu by Toofan Express at 5pm.

anchor.surface_text: Kanjilal informed the appellant by telephone on July 16 that the meeting would be on the 18th and that Basu would be reaching Dhanbad by the Toofan Express at about 5 p.m.

facts.text: Trap party reached Dhanbad by Toofan Express on July 18, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The trap arrangements were companypleted and the trap-party reached Dhanbad by the Toofan Express on July 18. Kanjilal himself went to Sindhri on the morning of July 18 and companyfirmed the arrangement to the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant reached Dhanbad railway station at about 5 p.m. on July 18, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant also reached Dhanbad railway station at about 5p.m. The members of the trap party took their seats at different tables in the companyners of the Refreshment Room of Kellners Restaurant.

facts.text: Basu passed envelope containing Rs.10,000 currency notes to appellant at Kelner Refreshment Room, appellant put it in trouser pocket, trap party recovered same marked notes.

anchor.surface_text: Basu, with the appellant, reached there and occupied another table. Refreshments were taken. Thereafter, Basu talked over matters about the companytract with the appellant, moved near him, took out the file from his satchel and then, after some companyversation, took out the envelope companytaining the currency numberes of the value of Rs. 10,000 and having its one long edge slit. This envelope was passed on to the appellant.

facts.text: When case taken up by Special Judge Patna on October 23, 1952, accused and Public Prosecutor desired de novo trial, no objection to jurisdiction then.

anchor.surface_text: When the case was taken up by the Special Judge, Patna, on October 23, 1952, the accused as well as the Public Prosecutor desired de numbero trial. No objection to the jurisdiction of the Court to try the case was taken at that time.

facts.text: Appellant failed to provide acceptable explanation for his presence at Dhanbad railway station on July 18, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Courts below have found companyroboration of the statements of Basu from the circumstances that the demand of money in December 1950 was mentioned in June, 1951, to Mr. K. N. Mookerjee that the trap must have been laid when Basu must have been certain that the appellant would turn up at Dhanbad at the appointed time and that the appellants presence at Dhanbad railway station companyld number have been accidental but must have been the result of previous arrangement.

issues.text: Whether there had been proper corroboration of the statement of Basu about the accused demanding the bribe and accepting the amount as illegal gratification?

anchor.surface_text: The last contention for consideration is whether there had been proper corroboration of the statement of Basu about the accused demanding the bribe of Rs. 10,000 and accepting it on July 18, 1951, at the Kelner Refreshment Room, Dhanbad Railway Station.

holdings.text: Section 4 has been enacted by Parliament and therefore it must be held that what it lays down is a procedure established by law.

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 has been enacted by Parliament and therefore it must be held that what it lays down is a procedure established by law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following A.K. Gopalan v. State of Madras, the word 'law' in Art. 21 means State-made law, not abstract principles of natural justice; s.4 of PCA enacted by Parliament qualifies as such procedure.

holdings.text: We do not consider this question to be a substantial question of law for the purpose of Art. 145(3)...

anchor.surface_text: We do not consider this question to be a substantial question of law for the purpose of Art. 145(3), which lays down that the minimum number of Judges who are to sit for the purpose of deciding any case involving a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of the Constitution shall be five,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Challenge to s.4 PCA under Art.21 not substantial constitutional question requiring five judges.

holdings.text: the provisions of s. 526 of the Criminal Procedure Code empowering the High Court to transfer any case from a criminal Court subordinate to it to any other Court competent to try it, apply to the case before any special Judge.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the provisions of s. 526 of the Criminal Procedure Code empowering the High Court to transfer any case from a criminal Court subordinate to it to any other Court competent to try it, apply to the case before any special Judge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.8(3) CLA Act applies CrPC provisions not inconsistent, deems Special Judge as Court of Session; s.526 transfer power thus available to High Court for Special Judge courts.

holdings.text: In view of s. 531 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, the order of the Special Judge, Patna, is not to be set aside on the ground of his having no territorial jurisdiction to try this case, when no failure of justice has actually taken place.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.531 CrPC applies via s.8(3) CLA as no inconsistency with s.7(1) or s.10; accused requested Patna transfer, sought de novo trial, no timely objection, no prejudice.

holdings.text: No infirmity can be found in this reasoning.

anchor.surface_text: No infirmity can be found in this reasoning.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Circumstantial corroboration: prior complaint in June 1951 mentioning Dec 1950 demand; trap laid with certainty of accused presence; presence not accidental but pre-arranged; marked notes recovery.

holdings.text: But we are of opinion that this omission has not occasioned any failure of justice.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Omission to question accused under s.342 CrPC on specific points (demand, meetings) no failure of justice as accused aware of case, denied main allegation of receiving bribe.

holdings.text: We are therefore of opinion that the appellant knew when he took the envelope from Basu that he was getting Rs. 10,000 as bribe, which amount he had demanded, and that therefore the conviction of the appellant is correct.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Implausible defence: pocketed fat envelope without inquiry; presence by arrangement not for papers (which could be posted); combined with corroboration supports knowledge of bribe.
